summary.p: A Deggwā (Antiphonary) with musical notation for the whole year. The manuscript also contains the Ṣoma deggwā (Antiphony for Lent), which is somewhat exceptional. The manuscript was copied during the reign of Emperor Iyasu II (1730 to 1755).

The name of the book is given as Berbere (sic).

foliation.p: Modern pencil foliation in Arabic numerals on the upper right corner of each recto folio.
Unnumbered folio between folios 105v and 106r; folioation is missing between 105v and 106r; 128rv has been duplicated .

collation.p: Sections are composed primarily of 4 bifolios.

layout.p: Folios have been pricked and scored to assist in writing, though on some folios the scoring lines are so heavy they are causing splits in the parchment.

handNote.p: Written in a Ge'ez script, in black and red ink, by a single hand; very small excellent handwriting with musical notation.

additions.p: On 2r 'Hymns' and at the bottom an ornamental band in black ink.
On 7r and throughout, marginalia minuscule corrections about 1 mm in height, in an excellent hand.

binding.p: Ethiopic binding. Exposed wooden boards, thick and smooth with a slight rounding of the three external edges. Parchment spine lining made of Ethiopic manuscript waste, not adhered but slotted around the four sewing stations with 5 protruding flaps inside the covers. Front board has a vertical split down the centre and has been repaired with three sets of looped thread. Leather remnants inside the boards of both boards suggest it may have been covered at some point. No endbands extant. Unsupported sewing at 4 stations (two even pairs of sewing stations). The sewing is laced into the boards as an integral part of the sewing process and is done in separate pairs with each pair sewn using a different thread. Sewing is broken between folios 87-88 and 88-95 is partially loose. Knots between folios 83-84 and 99-100 to secure sewing suggest it has been repaired, though this repair is failing.

Traditional two-part brown leather slip case. Split braid leather loop on the top of the box. Long carrying strap only remains attached on the right side with two strips of leather. Blind tooled decoration. Fragile with damage to the leather and sewing starting to break along the joins.

provenance.p: A marginal note on 5r indicates the manuscript belonged at one time to the Church of the Saviour of the World located at Āmba Maryam (i.e. Magdala) and would have been taken by a member of the British army in 1867-1868.
Another marginal note on 172r indicates the manuscript belonged at one time to Lalībela.

James Ludovic Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford (1847-1913) . The inner upper cover (pastedown) bears the armorial bookplate (Ex Libris) identifying the codex as having once been part of the Bibliotheca Lindesiana, the private library of the Lindsay family, Earls of Crawford and Balcarres | Armorial bookplate (Ex Libris): ARMS: Quarterly, 1st and 4th, Gules a fess chequy Argent and Azure; 2nd and 3rd, Or a lion rampant Gules, debruised of a ribbon in bend Sable. CREST: a swan’s head, neck, and wings proper, issuing from an antique ducal coronet Or. SUPPORTERS: two lions, rampant guardant Gules. MOTTO in Latin: Endure fort (Endure bravely) | Bibliotheca Lindesiana | pencilled: 5/G. Pencilled on left inner upper cover: Ethiopic MSS | No 4.
Purchased by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) in 1901 from James Ludovic Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford (1847-1913).
